unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Two-Proportion Z-Interval: Conditions
question_text:
A high school athletic director was interested whether high school males are more likely to compete in sports than high school females are.
He randomly sampled $200$ high school males across the country and found that $82$ of them participated in at least one high school sport at some point during the year. This compares to $68$ out of $200$ randomly sampled high school females who participated in at least one sport during the year.
Suppose the athletic director wanted to perform a two-proportion $Z$-interval.
In addition to needing two independent random samples, another necessary condition is

choices.text: Sample sizes must be large, say at least $30$ each.
Combined sample sizes must be large, say at least $30$.
$200 \cdot (0.34)$ and $200\cdot (0.41)$ must both be at least $5$, as well as $200\cdot (0.66)$ and $200 \cdot (0.59)$.
The parent population must be roughly normal.

solution:
Conditions for a two-proportion $Z$-interval include:

n1p̂1≥5
n2p̂2≥5
n1(1−p̂1)≥5
n2(1−p̂2)≥5

...where n1 and n2 are sample sizes, and p̂1 and p̂2 are sample proportions.

Note that Choices 'A', 'B', and 'E' hint at conditions for sample means, not proportions, making them incorrect.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.

Note that some textbook use a value of 10, instead of 5 for the n*p conditions.
